comment.author: 24471757@N00
comment._content: Remarkable photo! Amazing how the ship dwarfs the buildings in the foreground.

comment.author: 29050464@N06
comment._content:
Very cool photo.

Does anyone know a bit about the ship? My feeble Google search didn't turn it up.

comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: The Ottawa was one of a large number of ships to bear this name, but this particular one was a tanker built at Swan Hunter's Wallsend yard in 1964 for Trident Tankers Ltd.

comment.author: 29050464@N06
comment._content: Thanks. I'll go with "launched in 1964" per above. Added to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swan_Hunter Thanks for posting these!

comment.author: 81038844@N07
comment._content: This was the first ship I worked on after being transferred on completing my apprenticeship at the Wallsend Slipway. It was 87,000 tonnes and I think it was propelled with a gas turbine engine. The photo was taken on land behind the Hebburn ferry landing on the bottom left of the picture. The Esso Northumbria was 256,000 tonnes

comment.author: 52114507@N07
comment._content: Very good photo, you can even see the clouds of rust coming off the drag chains ( by the port bow obscuring the bottom of the hammerhead crane). The description needs amending though, this would definitely not be visible from South Shields,  Jim H5 is right, its taken from Hebburn. The Ottawa was steam turbine though.
